articles.headline: How Outdoor Voices, a Start-Up Darling, Imploded
articles.snippet: The founder was pushed out after clashing with experienced executives, highlighting a generational and gender divide within the clothing retailer.
articles.abstract: The founder was pushed out after clashing with experienced executives, highlighting a generational and gender divide within the clothing retailer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, Tyler Haney, the founder and chief executive of Outdoor Voices, appeared to be golden.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: How Your Airbnb Host Is Feeling the Pain of the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: Online travel sites, including Booking.com and Airbnb, are facing a world of hurt as people all but stop taking trips.
articles.abstract: Online travel sites, including Booking.com and Airbnb, are facing a world of hurt as people all but stop taking trips.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Livia De Felice, who owns two vacation rental properties and manages four others across Italy, has seen all of her bookings for March canceled, leaving her “extremely worried,” she said.

articles.headline: Sanders and Biden Cancel Events as Coronavirus Fears Upend Primary
articles.snippet: The presidential race entered extraordinary new ground as the leading Democrats called off primary-night events in Cleveland, and President Trump’s signature rallies also faced an uncertain future.
articles.abstract: The presidential race entered extraordinary new ground as the leading Democrats called off primary-night events in Cleveland, and President Trump’s signature rallies also faced an uncertain future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s presidential race entered an unpredictable new phase on Tuesday after the two leading Democratic candidates canceled big primary-night campaign events because of worries about the coronavirus, and Vice President Mike Pence said that the future of President Trump’s signature rallies would be decided on a “a day-to-day basis.”
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember, Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Economic Prescription for Coronavirus: ‘You’ve Got to Go Fast’
articles.snippet: Policymakers can’t prevent economic damage from the outbreak, but they can limit it and make a quick rebound more likely.
articles.abstract: Policymakers can’t prevent economic damage from the outbreak, but they can limit it and make a quick rebound more likely.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government can’t prevent the coronavirus from damaging the U.S. economy.

articles.headline: Talks Begin on Stimulus Plan as Trump Plays Down Virus Threat
articles.snippet: A proposal to eliminate payroll taxes through the end of the year, estimated to cost $700 billion, faces bipartisan opposition, but some version of it could be the basis for a broad agreement to provide aid.
articles.abstract: A proposal to eliminate payroll taxes through the end of the year, estimated to cost $700 billion, faces bipartisan opposition, but some version of it could be the basis for a broad agreement to provide aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and lawmakers began negotiations on Tuesday for an emergency relief package to bolster an economy battered by the coronavirus crisis, with lawmakers and administration officials expressing optimism despite partisan divisions about what to include.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: ‘It’s Just Everywhere Already’: How Delays in Testing Set Back the U.S. Coronavirus Response
articles.snippet: A series of missed chances by the federal government to ensure more widespread testing came during the early days of the outbreak, when containment would have been easier.
articles.abstract: A series of missed chances by the federal government to ensure more widespread testing came during the early days of the outbreak, when containment would have been easier.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Helen Y. Chu, an infectious disease expert in Seattle, knew that the United States did not have much time.
articles.byline: By Sheri Fink and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Biden Takes Command of Race, Winning Four States Including Michigan
articles.snippet: Joseph R. Biden Jr. widened his advantage over Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary race, capturing Mississippi and Missouri as well as Michigan, with support from both black and white voters.
articles.abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. widened his advantage over Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary race, capturing Mississippi and Missouri as well as Michigan, with support from both black and white voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. took command of the Democratic presidential race in decisive fashion on Tuesday, marshaling a powerful multiracial coalition in the South and the Midwest that swept aside Senator Bernie Sanders and completed Mr. Biden’s rapid transformation from a sometimes-fumbling underdog into his party’s likely nominee.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Let’s Talk About Coronavirus Bailouts, Before We Need Them
articles.snippet: In 2008, policymakers rescued the economy but raised a divisive debate about the fairness of using tax dollars to save companies. Get ready for a repeat.
articles.abstract: In 2008, policymakers rescued the economy but raised a divisive debate about the fairness of using tax dollars to save companies. Get ready for a repeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bailouts. Stimulus. Corporate socialism. Welfare for business.

articles.headline: Coronavirus May Light Fuse on ‘Unexploded Bomb’ of Corporate Debt
articles.snippet: A surge of risky borrowing by companies around the world leaves the global economy especially exposed to the potential costs of the outbreak.
articles.abstract: A surge of risky borrowing by companies around the world leaves the global economy especially exposed to the potential costs of the outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — To grasp why the most important central banks — from the Fed to the Bank of England to the Bank of Japan — are now leaping into action as if the world were on fire, it helps to examine the subject of corporate debt.

articles.headline: Behind Bernie Sanders’s Decision to Stay in the Race
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders said he was not dropping out, but aides said he recognized time was running short. He listed a series of policy items in what could be seen as a wish list of concessions he would want.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders said he was not dropping out, but aides said he recognized time was running short. He listed a series of policy items in what could be seen as a wish list of concessions he would want.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Senator Bernie Sanders on Wednesday made a defiant case for his liberal policy agenda despite suffering big losses in the Democratic primaries this week, saying he planned to continue his bid for the presidency. But he acknowledged that he was “losing the debate over electability” to his rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember, Reid J. Epstein and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: U.S. to Suspend Most Travel From Europe as World Scrambles to Fight Pandemic
articles.snippet: President Trump addressed the nation from the Oval Office on Wednesday night.
articles.abstract: President Trump addressed the nation from the Oval Office on Wednesday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday night blocked most visitors from continental Europe to the United States and vowed emergency aid to workers and small businesses as the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus a pandemic, stock markets plunged further and millions of people cut themselves off from their regular lives.
